'''Swami X''' was an American [[boardwalk]] performer and stand-up comedian. Active from the 1970s to 1985, he performed in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Berkeley, and New York. He was known for bawdy sexual humor and political invective.<ref name="kcet"/><ref name=campbell>{{cite book |first=Patricia J |last=Campbell |title=Passing the Hat - Street Performers in America |year= 1981 |location=New York |publisher=Delacorte Press<!--|ISBN= 978-0-440-06824-2-->|ISBN= 978-0-385-28771-5 |oclc= 7461199 }}</ref>
Swami X's act was a monologue mixing pithy sociopolitical observations with poetry, sarcasm and humor, which typically included blasphemy, profanity, and attacking "sacred cows"â€”producing "pleased shock and delighted outrage" in observers.<ref name=campbell/> His notable lines include: *"Sex is not the answer. Sex is the question. [[yes and no|'Yes' is the answer]]."<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Weiss | first1 = Stefanie Iris. | title = Eco-sex : go green between the sheets and make your love life sustainable | year = 2010 | publisher = Ten Speed Press | location = New York | isbn = 978-1-58008-118-4 | page = 197}}</ref> *"How do we know [[Jesus Christ]] was Jewish? Because he went into His Father's business."<ref name=campbell/> *"If I had known I would live this long, I would have taken better care of myself". *"You are what you eat. If that's true, then I'm a nymphomaniac".
He was known for appearing on the Venice Boardwalk, at the UCLA and U.C. Berkeley campuses, in San Francisco, and at Washington Park in New York City. He retired in 1985.<ref name="kcet">{{cite web|title=SWAMI X - Comedian|url=http://www.kcet.org/socal/departures/venice/the-crumbs/swami-x---comedian.html|publisher=KCET website|accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> In 2009 the mayor of Los Angeles, [[Antonio Villaraigosa]], presented him with an official proclamation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.venicepaper.net/pmt_more.php?id=454_0_1_0_M "Villaraigosa |title=Honors Swami X; Blows Off Officially Running for Gov |publisher= ''The Venice Paper'' |date=22 June 2009}}</ref>
Swami X appears as a character in [[Roger L. Simon]]'s mystery novel, ''The Straight Man''<ref>{{cite book|title=The Straight Man|first=Roger L. |last=Simon|year=1986|publisher=Villard Books|pages=46, 88, 91|isbn=978-0-394-55837-0}}</ref> and is referenced in Pat Hartman's volume of Venice vignettes, ''Call Someplace Paradise''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Call Someplace Paradise|first=Pat |last=Hartman|publisher=Xlibris |year=2000|isbn=978-0-7388-2005-7|page=93}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=January 2018}}</ref>
Harry W. "Swami X" Hart died on August 29, 2015 at the home of former Los Angeles City Councilman Bill Rosendahl. He was 89, two and a half months before his 90th birthday. Hart was born in Philadelphia in mid-November 1925.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/venice-beach-comic-swami-x-is-dead-at-89-5985241 |title=Venice Beach Comic Swami X Is Dead at 89|publisher=''L.A. Weekly'' |date=1 September 2015}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=https://freevenicebeachhead.org/2015/10/17/swami-x-has-left-the-building|title=Swami X Has Left the Building|publisher=''Free Venice. Beachhead'' |date=1 September 2015}}</ref>
